objective.title: (Objective)

stem: A customer uses a previously configured smartphone to interact with a payment terminal to purchase an item. Which of the following technologies is the smartphone using?
explanation: Near-field communication (NFC) is commonly used for tap-to-pay transactions. RFID is similar but not typically used for smartphone payments, 802.11 is Wi‑Fi, and Bluetooth is a short-range peripheral/pairing technology.

rationales.RFID: RFID is used for tags/badges; smartphones commonly use NFC for payments.
rationales.NFC: Correct. NFC enables secure short-range tap-to-pay transactions.
rationales.802.11: 802.11 refers to Wi‑Fi networking, not tap payments.
rationales.Bluetooth: Bluetooth is used for pairing peripherals, not typical payment terminals.

objective.title: Given a scenario, monitor mobile device hardware and use appropriate replacement

stem: Which technology or feature is being used in the following scenario: A company needs to enforce passcode policy and enable remote wipe on employee phones.
explanation: OBJ 1.1: MDM is correct. Mobile device management used to enforce policies and remote wipe corporate devices. NFC: NFC is not the best match. Uses very short‑range radio (a few cm) for tap‑to‑pay and pairing. Tethering (USB): Tethering (USB) is not the best match. Shares internet to a computer over USB; often more stable than Wi‑Fi hotspot. Biometrics: Biometrics is not the best match. Fingerprint/face recognition used for authentication. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: 130b681d56120124 in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.3: Incorrect. Biometrics is not the best match. Fingerprint/face recognition used for authentication.

objective.title: (Objective)

stem: A user's mobile phone has stopped charging. After inspecting the port for dirt or debris, which of the following steps should a technician perform next to diagnose the issue?
options: Restore the phone to factory defaults.
Send the phone to the vendor for replacement.
explanation: Using a known-good cable (and charger) isolates the problem quickly and non-destructively. Restarting may help with software issues but is less likely after a physical inspection, and factory reset or vendor replacement are later steps.

A restart can help, but hardware isolation with a known-good cable/charger is the next best diagnostic step.
A factory reset is destructive and should not be done before basic hardware checks.
Correct. Swap in known-good accessories to isolate a cable/charger fault.
rationales.Send the phone to the vendor for replace: Vendor replacement is a later step after basic diagnostics.

objective.title: (Objective)

stem: Which of the following is used to register inputs on a touch-screen monitor?
explanation: A digitizer detects touch input and converts it into digital signals the system can interpret. An inverter powers backlights in some LCDs, while OLED and LCD describe display technologies rather than touch input components.

rationales.Inverter: An inverter is associated with powering backlights for some LCD panels, not detecting touch.
rationales.Digitizer: Correct. A digitizer registers touch input.
rationales.OLED: OLED is a display technology; it does not specifically indicate touch input capability.
rationales.LCD: LCD is a display technology; it does not specifically indicate touch input capability.

objective.title: Explain wireless networking technologies.

stem: A technician is upgrading an office WLAN and needs a standard that supports OFDMA and improved performance in congested environments. Which standard should be selected?
explanation: OBJ 2.2: Operates on 2.4/5/6 GHz (Wi‑Fi 6/6E) and can reach up to 9.6 Gbps; OFDMA improves efficiency. 802.11ac: Operates on 5 GHz and can reach ~3.5 Gbps with wider channels/MU‑MIMO; Wi‑Fi 5. 802.11g: Operates on 2.4 GHz and offers up to 54 Mbps; Wi‑Fi 3. 802.11a: Operates on 5 GHz and offers up to 54 Mbps; legacy Wi‑Fi 2. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: ea5555a595fc0939 in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.0: Incorrect. Operates on 5 GHz and can reach ~3.5 Gbps with wider channels/MU‑MIMO; Wi‑Fi 5.

rationales.2: Incorrect. Operates on 2.4 GHz and offers up to 54 Mbps; Wi‑Fi 3.
rationales.3: Incorrect. Operates on 5 GHz and offers up to 54 Mbps; legacy Wi‑Fi 2.

For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: b40d1dc79c9f111a in your ticket. Thank you.

stem: A technician needs to allow DHCP client traffic through a firewall for remote administration. Which port should be opened?
explanation: OBJ 2.3: DHCP client commonly uses port 68. Client port for DHCP (server uses UDP 67). 110: Port 110 is typically used by POP3. Email retrieval protocol; POP3S is 995. 22: Port 22 is typically used by SSH. Secure remote shell access to manage systems over TCP. 25: Port 25 is typically used by SMTP. Email transfer between mail servers. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: 6021d6d32261c076 in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.1: Incorrect. Port 110 is typically used by POP3. Email retrieval protocol; POP3S is 995.
rationales.2: Incorrect. Port 22 is typically used by SSH. Secure remote shell access to manage systems over TCP.
rationales.3: Incorrect. Port 25 is typically used by SMTP. Email transfer between mail servers.

stem: Which of the following devices/services is used to monitor and analyze system events across networked devices?
explanation: OBJ 2.3: A syslog server collects and stores log data from networked devices (routers, switches, servers, firewalls). Centralizing logs makes it easier to monitor events and troubleshoot across many systems. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: bc1a2485e3f981c6 in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.0: Incorrect. Authentication server primarily centralizes identity and access control (AAA).
rationales.1: Correct. A syslog server centralizes logs from many systems for review and troubleshooting.
rationales.2: Incorrect. DHCP server primarily assigns IP addresses automatically.
rationales.3: Incorrect. DNS server primarily resolves names to IP addresses.
rationales.4: Incorrect. Print server primarily manages print queues and printer sharing.
rationales.5: Incorrect. Load balancer primarily distributes traffic across multiple servers.

explanation: OBJ 2.3: A syslog server collects and stores log data from networked devices (routers, switches, servers, firewalls). Centralizing logs makes it easier to monitor events and troubleshoot across many systems. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: 41aa7275983ea379 in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.0: Incorrect. DNS server primarily resolves names to IP addresses.
rationales.1: Incorrect. DHCP server primarily assigns IP addresses automatically.
rationales.2: Incorrect. Load balancer primarily distributes traffic across multiple servers.
rationales.3: Incorrect. Authentication server primarily centralizes identity and access control (AAA).
rationales.4: Correct. A syslog server centralizes logs from many systems for review and troubleshooting.
rationales.5: Incorrect. Print server primarily manages print queues and printer sharing.

objective.title: Compare and contrast internet connection types, network types, and their

stem: Which 802.11 standard operates on 2.4 GHz and has a maximum theoretical data rate of about 11 Mbps?
explanation: OBJ 2.7: 802.11b (Wi‑Fi 1/2) matches the band/features in the scenario. It is commonly associated with a maximum theoretical throughput of about 11 Mbps and operates on 2.4 GHz. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: 63b2b79faa3288a3 in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.0: Incorrect. 802.11n typically uses 2.4/5 GHz and tops out around 600 Mbps.
rationales.1: Incorrect. 802.11ac typically uses 5 GHz and tops out around 3.5 Gbps.
rationales.2: Incorrect. 802.11a typically uses 5 GHz and tops out around 54 Mbps.
rationales.3: Correct. This standard matches the band/features and speed described.
rationales.4: Incorrect. 802.11g typically uses 2.4 GHz and tops out around 54 Mbps.
rationales.5: Incorrect. 802.11ax typically uses 2.4/5/6 GHz and tops out around 9.6 Gbps.

explanation: OBJ 2.7: 802.11g (Wi‑Fi 3) matches the band/features in the scenario. It is commonly associated with a maximum theoretical throughput of about 54 Mbps and operates on 2.4 GHz. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: e961dd587a1ef85c in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.0: Incorrect. 802.11a typically uses 5 GHz and tops out around 54 Mbps.
rationales.1: Incorrect. 802.11n typically uses 2.4/5 GHz and tops out around 600 Mbps.
rationales.2: Incorrect. 802.11ac typically uses 5 GHz and tops out around 3.5 Gbps.
rationales.3: Correct. This standard matches the band/features and speed described.
rationales.4: Incorrect. 802.11b typically uses 2.4 GHz and tops out around 11 Mbps.
rationales.5: Incorrect. 802.11ax typically uses 2.4/5/6 GHz and tops out around 9.6 Gbps.

objective.title: Compare and contrast internet connection types, network types, and their

stem: Which of the following types of networks BEST matches the following description: local area network (single site/building)?
explanation: OBJ 2.7: A LAN is a local area network (single site/building). It is defined mainly by its geographic scope and typical use case. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: caa54599ccb22840 in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.0: Correct. This network type matches the scope and purpose described.
rationales.1: Incorrect. WAN is typically used for region/country scope (wide area network (multiple sites/regions)).
rationales.2: Incorrect. PAN is typically used for a few meters scope (personal area network (short range around a person)).
rationales.3: Incorrect. WLAN is typically used for building scope (wireless LAN using 802.11).
rationales.4: Incorrect. SAN is typically used for datacenter scope (storage area network (high-speed storage fabric)).
rationales.5: Incorrect. MAN is typically used for city scope (metropolitan area network (city-wide)).

rationales.0: Incorrect. WAN is typically used for region/country scope (wide area network (multiple sites/regions)).
rationales.1: Incorrect. MAN is typically used for city scope (metropolitan area network (city-wide)).
rationales.2: Incorrect. PAN is typically used for a few meters scope (personal area network (short range around a person)).
rationales.3: Correct. This network type matches the scope and purpose described.
rationales.4: Incorrect. LAN is typically used for building scope (local area network (single site/building)).
rationales.5: Incorrect. SAN is typically used for datacenter scope (storage area network (high-speed storage fabric)).

objective.title: (Objective)

stem: Which of the following would be the best technology for a device to wirelessly connect to a speaker?
explanation: Bluetooth is designed for short-range peripheral and audio connectivity and is commonly used to pair speakers and headsets. Wi‑Fi is typically used for LAN connectivity, NFC is short-range tap-to-pair and payment, and 5G is a cellular WAN technology.

rationales.Wi-Fi: Wi‑Fi is for LAN/WLAN networking, not typical for pairing a single speaker peripheral.
rationales.NFC: NFC is extremely short-range and used for tap-to-pair or payments, not ongoing audio transport.
rationales.5G: 5G is a cellular WAN technology used for internet access, not local peripheral pairing.
rationales.Bluetooth: Correct. Bluetooth supports low-power short-range connections and common audio profiles.

objective.title: Compare and contrast internet connection types, network types, and their

stem: Which type of network best fits this scenario: A city provides municipal connectivity across multiple districts.
explanation: OBJ 2.7: MAN is correct. Covers a metropolitan area such as a city; larger than a LAN, smaller than a WAN. LAN: LAN is not correct for this scope. Connects devices within a limited area like a home, office, or building. SAN: SAN is not correct for this scope. Dedicated high‑speed network that provides block‑level storage to servers. WLAN: WLAN is not correct for this scope. A LAN implemented wirelessly (typically using 802.11). For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: 7c636e583668c1ac in your ticket. Thank you.

objective.title: Compare and contrast internet connection types, network types, and their

stem: Which type of wireless network utilizes the 5 GHz frequency band and reaches theoretical speeds of up to 3.5 Gbps?
explanation: OBJ 2.7: 802.11ac (Wi‑Fi 5) matches the band/features in the scenario. It is commonly associated with a maximum theoretical throughput of about 3.5 Gbps and operates on 5 GHz. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: f0dbd806d8b3c42e in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.0: Incorrect. 802.11ax typically uses 2.4/5/6 GHz and tops out around 9.6 Gbps.
rationales.1: Incorrect. 802.11n typically uses 2.4/5 GHz and tops out around 600 Mbps.
rationales.2: Incorrect. 802.11a typically uses 5 GHz and tops out around 54 Mbps.
rationales.3: Correct. This standard matches the band/features and speed described.
rationales.4: Incorrect. 802.11g typically uses 2.4 GHz and tops out around 54 Mbps.
rationales.5: Incorrect. 802.11b typically uses 2.4 GHz and tops out around 11 Mbps.

objective.title: (Objective)

stem: A technician needs to install the appropriate RAM for a performance-intensive gaming desktop computer. Which of the following technologies will the technician most likely select?
explanation: A modern gaming desktop benefits most from a current-generation, high-bandwidth memory technology such as DDR5. Registered/ECC memory is typically used in servers/workstations, and single-channel is a configuration that reduces bandwidth compared to dual-channel.

rationales.Non-ECC: Non‑ECC is common in desktops, but it is not a performance technology choice by itself.
rationales.Single channel: Single-channel reduces memory bandwidth and is not preferred for performance builds.
rationales.Registered: Registered (buffered) memory is typically used in servers, not gaming desktops.
rationales.DDR5: Correct. DDR5 provides higher bandwidth and improved efficiency compared to prior generations.

objective.title: Summarize basic cable types and their connectors, features, and purposes.

stem: Which connector would be the best choice for the following requirement: A docking station uses a high‑speed link that carries PCIe devices and DisplayPort video over USB‑C.
explanation: OBJ 3.2: Thunderbolt is the best fit. High‑speed interface that can carry PCIe and DisplayPort; often uses USB‑C connector. USB-C (DisplayPort Alt Mode): USB-C (DisplayPort Alt Mode) is not the best match here. USB‑C can carry DisplayPort video using Alt Mode; depends on device support. HDMI: HDMI is not the best match here. Common digital audio/video connector for TVs/monitors; supports CEC and audio. DisplayPort: DisplayPort is not the best match here. Digital display interface common on PCs; supports high refresh and daisy‑chaining (MST). For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: 30bb5f45d683c518 in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.3: Incorrect. DisplayPort is not the best match here. Digital display interface common on PCs; supports high refresh and daisy‑chaining (MST).

explanation: OBJ 3.2: HDMI is the best fit. Common digital audio/video connector for TVs/monitors; supports CEC and audio. Thunderbolt: Thunderbolt is not the best match here. High‑speed interface that can carry PCIe and DisplayPort; often uses USB‑C connector. DVI: DVI is not the best match here. Digital (and sometimes analog) video connector; no native audio. DisplayPort: DisplayPort is not the best match here. Digital display interface common on PCs; supports high refresh and daisy‑chaining (MST). For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: b7c9f6313e97fd05 in your ticket. Thank you.

stem: A technician needs to meet this requirement: A desktop PC uses standard consumer RAM without error correction. Which technology should the technician select?
explanation: OBJ 3.3: Non‑ECC is the correct selection. Standard consumer memory; does not provide error correction. ECC: ECC is not the best selection for this requirement. Error‑correcting memory used in many servers to detect/correct bit errors; requires platform support. Registered (buffered): Registered (buffered) is not the best selection for this requirement. Server memory type that buffers address/control signals; used for high capacity/stability. SO‑DIMM: SO‑DIMM is not the best selection for this requirement. Smaller form factor used in laptops and small‑form‑factor PCs. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: e3357cd7d85a3b0e in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.3: Incorrect. SO‑DIMM is not the best selection for this requirement. Smaller form factor used in laptops and small‑form‑factor PCs.

Non‑ECC: Non‑ECC is not the best selection for this requirement. Standard consumer memory; does not provide error correction. SO‑DIMM: SO‑DIMM is not the best selection for this requirement. Smaller form factor used in laptops and small‑form‑factor PCs. DDR5: DDR5 is not the best selection for this requirement. Newer memory generation with higher bandwidth and improved power management on-module. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: 7d1dd930c9bcadb8 in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.0: Correct. ECC is the correct selection. Error‑correcting memory used in many servers to detect/correct bit errors; requires platform support.
rationales.1: Incorrect. Non‑ECC is not the best selection for this requirement. Standard consumer memory; does not provide error correction.
rationales.2: Incorrect. SO‑DIMM is not the best selection for this requirement. Smaller form factor used in laptops and small‑form‑factor PCs.
rationales.3: Incorrect. DDR5 is not the best selection for this requirement. Newer memory generation with higher bandwidth and improved power management on-module.

stem: A technician needs to meet this requirement: A technician is building a performance‑intensive gaming desktop and wants the latest mainstream consumer memory generation. Which technology should the technician select?
explanation: OBJ 3.3: DDR5 is the correct selection. Newer memory generation with higher bandwidth and improved power management on-module. Registered (buffered): Registered (buffered) is not the best selection for this requirement. Server memory type that buffers address/control signals; used for high capacity/stability. ECC: ECC is not the best selection for this requirement. Error‑correcting memory used in many servers to detect/correct bit errors; requires platform support. DDR4: DDR4 is not the best selection for this requirement. Common desktop/laptop memory generation; lower bandwidth than DDR5. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: 6b83a69afb9e128b in your ticket. Thank you.

objective.title: (Objective)

stem: Which of the following cable types is used to connect a display?
explanation: DVI is a video interface used to connect monitors. RJ45 is Ethernet, SATA is for storage devices, and USB 1.1 is an older peripheral interface not typically used as a primary display cable.

rationales.DVI: Correct. DVI is a display/video connector.
rationales.RJ45: RJ45 is an Ethernet connector used for network cabling.
rationales.SATA: SATA connects internal storage devices (HDD/SSD) to the motherboard.
rationales.USB 1.1: USB 1.1 is an old USB standard; display connections typically use HDMI/DP/DVI/VGA/USB‑C Alt Mode.

stem: Which RAID level best fits this requirement: A database server needs high performance and redundancy; the company can afford additional disks.
explanation: OBJ 3.5: RAID 10 is the best match. Striping + mirroring; high performance and redundancy; requires multiple disks. RAID 5: RAID 5 is not the best match. Striping with distributed parity; tolerates one disk failure. RAID 0: RAID 0 is not the best match. Striping only; improves performance but provides no fault tolerance. RAID 1: RAID 1 is not the best match. Mirroring; provides redundancy at the cost of capacity. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: a36aa7d4e0cde877 in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.1: Incorrect. RAID 5 is not the best match. Striping with distributed parity; tolerates one disk failure.
rationales.2: Incorrect. RAID 0 is not the best match. Striping only; improves performance but provides no fault tolerance.
rationales.3: Incorrect. RAID 1 is not the best match. Mirroring; provides redundancy at the cost of capacity.

objective.title: Given a scenario, install the appropriate power supply.

stem: A technician is troubleshooting a laser printer. Symptom: A laser printer outputs pages where toner wipes off easily when touched. Which component should be inspected or replaced first?
explanation: OBJ 3.6: Fuser is most likely at fault. Uses heat and pressure to bond toner to the paper in a laser printer. Pickup roller: Pickup roller is less likely for this symptom. Grabs paper from the tray to feed it into the printer path. Transfer roller: Transfer roller is less likely for this symptom. Moves toner from the drum onto the paper. Imaging drum: Imaging drum is less likely for this symptom. Holds the electrostatic image that attracts toner in a laser printer. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: a2c58de95cb87a87 in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.0: Incorrect. Pickup roller is less likely for this symptom. Grabs paper from the tray to feed it into the printer path.
rationales.1: Incorrect. Transfer roller is less likely for this symptom. Moves toner from the drum onto the paper.
rationales.2: Incorrect. Imaging drum is less likely for this symptom. Holds the electrostatic image that attracts toner in a laser printer.
rationales.3: Correct. Fuser is most likely at fault. Uses heat and pressure to bond toner to the paper in a laser printer.

objective.title: (Objective)

stem: A financial organization wants to establish an exclusive cloud instance. Which of the following cloud models should the organization adopt?
explanation: A private cloud is dedicated to a single organization and supports exclusive control and isolation. Public clouds are shared, hybrid combines private and public, and community clouds are shared among organizations with common requirements.

rationales.Hybrid: Hybrid combines private and public resources; it is not exclusively dedicated.
rationales.Community: Community clouds are shared by multiple organizations with similar needs.
rationales.Private: Correct. Private cloud resources are dedicated to one organization.
rationales.Public: Public cloud is multi-tenant and shared across many customers.

objective.title: Explain virtualization concepts.

stem: Which virtualization concept best matches this scenario: A cluster shares CPU and memory across VMs to improve utilization.
explanation: OBJ 4.1: Resource pooling is correct. Allocates shared compute/storage resources across workloads. Type 2 hypervisor: Type 2 hypervisor is not correct for this scenario. Runs on top of a host OS (hosted virtualization). VM snapshot: VM snapshot is not correct for this scenario. Point‑in‑time capture of a VM state for quick rollback. Type 1 hypervisor: Type 1 hypervisor is not correct for this scenario. Runs directly on hardware (bare‑metal) and hosts multiple VMs. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: d20593ccb68c67c0 in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.0: Incorrect. Type 2 hypervisor is not correct for this scenario. Runs on top of a host OS (hosted virtualization).
rationales.1: Correct. Resource pooling is correct. Allocates shared compute/storage resources across workloads.
rationales.2: Incorrect. VM snapshot is not correct for this scenario. Point‑in‑time capture of a VM state for quick rollback.
rationales.3: Incorrect. Type 1 hypervisor is not correct for this scenario. Runs directly on hardware (bare‑metal) and hosts multiple VMs.

objective.title: Summarize cloud computing concepts.

stem: Which cloud computing concept is BEST described as focusing on the replacement of physical hardware at a customer's location with cloud-based resources?
explanation: OBJ 4.2: Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) is used when you want the provider to supply the underlying compute, storage, and networking while you install and manage the OS and applications—effectively replacing on‑prem physical servers with rented virtual infrastructure. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: 9f9df2810d848fc2 in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.0: Incorrect. SECaaS is more closely associated with: security tools delivered as a service.
rationales.1: Incorrect. SaaS is more closely associated with: complete application delivered over the internet.
rationales.2: Incorrect. PaaS is more closely associated with: provider supplies runtime/platform; customer deploys code.
rationales.3: Correct. IaaS provides virtualized compute/storage/network while you manage the OS and software stack.

objective.title: Summarize cloud computing concepts.

stem: Which cloud deployment model best fits this requirement: A company wants to burst to the public cloud during peak demand while keeping sensitive data on‑prem.
explanation: OBJ 4.2: Hybrid cloud is the best match. Combination of private + public cloud with workload portability/integration. Community: Community cloud is not the best match for the scenario. objective.title: Given a scenario, troubleshoot motherboards, RAM, CPUs, and power.

stem: A laptop charges slowly and a known‑good AC adapter does not resolve the issue. Which component should be replaced next?
explanation: OBJ 5.1: A worn battery can accept charge slowly or not hold charge; replace it before the motherboard. TPM: The TPM relates to security/cryptography and does not affect charging. RAM: RAM issues cause instability/POST issues, not slow charging. LCD panel: The LCD panel is unrelated to power/charging behavior. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: 26af81ba83144a33 in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.0: Correct. A worn battery can accept charge slowly or not hold charge; replace it before the motherboard.
rationales.1: Incorrect. The TPM relates to security/cryptography and does not affect charging.
rationales.2: Incorrect. RAM issues cause instability/POST issues, not slow charging.
rationales.3: Incorrect. The LCD panel is unrelated to power/charging behavior.

objective.title: Given a scenario, troubleshoot motherboards, RAM, CPUs, and power.

stem: A PC's clock loses time after power is removed and the time resets every day.
explanation: OBJ 5.1: A depleted CMOS/RTC battery cannot maintain the real‑time clock settings when the system is off. Unseated RAM: Unseated RAM usually causes POST errors or crashes, not time drift/reset. GPU overheating: GPU overheating leads to artifacts or shutdowns, not incorrect system time. Corrupt driver: A corrupt driver affects device functionality, not the hardware real‑time clock. For support or reporting issues, include Question ID: 976ca6be56adf0d3 in your ticket. Thank you.

rationales.0: Correct. A depleted CMOS/RTC battery cannot maintain the real‑time clock settings when the system is off.
rationales.1: Incorrect. Unseated RAM usually causes POST errors or crashes, not time drift/reset.
rationales.2: Incorrect. GPU overheating leads to artifacts or shutdowns, not incorrect system time.
rationales.3: Incorrect. A corrupt driver affects device functionality, not the hardware real‑time clock.

objective.title: (Objective)

stem: A user brings a laptop in due to slow charging. The technician tries a different AC adapter, but it does not fix the issue. Which of the following components should the technician replace next?
explanation: If a known-good AC adapter does not resolve slow charging, the next most likely replaceable component is the battery. RAM and TPM are unrelated to charging performance, and a motherboard replacement is typically later after ruling out the battery/charging circuit.

rationales.Battery: Correct. A failing battery can cause slow charging or reduced charge capacity.
rationales.RAM: RAM does not affect charging behavior.
rationales.TPM: TPM is a security module; it does not affect charging.
rationales.Motherboard: Motherboard replacement is more invasive and usually follows battery and port checks.

objective.title: (Objective)

stem: A user reports slow internet browsing. The technician finds high CPU and memory usage, and pop-ups occur every minute. Which of the following should the technician do next?
options: Escalate to the network team to check end-to-end connectivity.
Download and install the latest drivers.
Update the anti-malware signatures and scan the system.
Check the wireless settings and validate the DHCP configuration.
explanation: High resource usage with frequent pop-ups is consistent with adware/malware. The next step is to update anti-malware definitions and run a scan to identify and remediate the infection before troubleshooting networking or drivers.

rationales.Escalate to the network team to check en: Symptoms point to a local infection rather than a network path issue.
Drivers rarely cause pop-ups and constant high CPU/memory usage.
rationales.Update the anti-malware signatures and s: Correct. This targets the most likely root cause: malware/adware.
rationales.Check the wireless settings and validate: DHCP/wireless misconfig would not typically cause pop-ups and high local resource usage.

objective.title: (Objective)

stem: A user's computer displays the wrong time. The user changes the time in system settings, which fixes it temporarily, but the time is wrong again after a day. Which of the following is most likely causing the issue?
explanation: A failing CMOS battery can cause the system clock (RTC) to lose time when the PC is powered off. Unseated RAM, a power cable issue, or a video card problem would not typically cause time/date settings to reset.

rationales.Unseated RAM: RAM issues usually cause instability or boot failures, not persistent time drift.
rationales.Power cable: A power cable issue would affect power delivery, not the RTC clock retention.
rationales.CMOS battery: Correct. The CMOS/RTC battery maintains BIOS settings and system time when powered off.
rationales.Video card: A video card affects display output, not system time.
